snippet: The ruling Communist Party sought to swiftly close ranks on Wednesday, a day after removing a once-powerful official and naming his wife as a murder suspect.
abstract: China's governing Communist Party seeks to close ranks swiftly, a day after removing a once-powerful official, Bo Xilai, from the party’s Politburo and naming his wife as the main suspect in the murder of a British businessman; party is hoping to move beyond scandal that has exposed a leadership split and threatens to lay bare corruption in the party’s highest ranks.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and SHARON LaFRANIERE
byline.contributor: Jonathan Ansfield contributed reporting. Li Bibo contributed research.

lead_paragraph: The ruling Communist Party sought to swiftly close ranks on Wednesday, a day after removing a once-powerful official and naming his wife as a murder suspect.

headline.seo: China Seeks to Contain Fallout From Scandal
headline.main: After Removal of Official, China Rushes to Unify Party and Limit Damage
headline.print_headline: After Removal of Official, China Rushes to Unify Party and Limit Damage
